title: Responding to the Mental and Physical Health Effects upon Young People of Life in High Crime, Low Income, Neighbourhoods
abstractText:
By developing our understanding of young peoples' coping mechanisms and how these are mediated via gender and ethnicity, the proposed Knowledge Exchange will indicate where gender- and ethnicity-specific, or gender and ethnicity neutral strategies and interventions may address differing types and levels of need and risk.

Through face-to-face, telephone and e.mail interviews/discussion with Brathay regional managers, we will establish the key issues and questions in the area of the physical and mental health and well-being of the targeted young people, raised for these practitioners at the levels of policy, administration and practice. This will be followed by a two-day residential seminar at the Brathay Trust's residential centre, to which we shall invite Brathay staff and academics with expertise in the relevant areas, from the Institute of Applied Social Research as well as visiting professors at the university. The outcomes will be collected in an edited book or a themed issue of a relevant journal.
